M9 minimal medium (M9)

The M9 minimal medium (M9) in silico definition consists of all compounds described by Sigma-Aldrich. M9 is a minimal medium commonly used in microbiology and was developed in 1988[1]. Since then, M9 has been adapted with different kinds of additives and used to gather insight into carbon or nitrogen sources[2]. The medium definition used in this study is based on the provider reference[3] and was further supplemented with ce{MgSO_4*7H_2O}, ce{CaCl_2*2H_2O} and Glucose.

Table 6 M9 composition

[1]

G. Bécard and J. A. Fortin. Early events of vesicular–arbuscular mycorrhiza formation on Ri T-DNA transformed roots. New Phytologist, 108(2):211–218, 1988. doi:10.1111/j.1469-8137.1988.tb03698.x.

[2]

Jane Hawkey, Ben Vezina, Jonathan M. Monk, Louise M. Judd, Taylor Harshegyi, Sebastián López-Fernández, Carla Rodrigues, Sylvain Brisse, Kathryn E. Holt, and Kelly L. Wyres. A curated collection of Klebsiella metabolic models reveals variable substrate usage and gene essentiality. Genome Research, 32(5):1004–1014, 2022. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9104693/ (visited on 2022-07-19), arXiv:35277433, doi:10.1101/gr.276289.121.

[3]

M9-minimalsalze, 5x powder, minimal microbial growth medium | sigma-aldrich. URL: http://www.sigmaaldrich.com/ (visited on 2023-03-24).
